sols_html:
A picture when k is 2 is drawn below.

To compute the area of S, we actually don’t need to do any more work. Notice that the area of the blue circle when y is greater than 0 is half the area of the unit circle which is \(\tfrac{\pi}{2}\). Now, the area of the ellipse when y is greater than 0 is again half the area of the ellipse, which by the previous problem is \(\tfrac{\pi(1)}{2}(\tfrac{1}{k}) = \tfrac{\pi}{2k}\). Hence, the area of S is

\(A = \frac{\pi}{2} - \frac{\pi}{2k} = \frac{\pi}{2}\left(1 - \frac{1}{k} \right).\)

Now, notice that when x is 0, then the two points on the ellipse are \(y = \pm \tfrac{1}{k}\). So the one lying in the upper half of the plane is \(y = \tfrac{1}{k}\). The question asks when is the centroid outside of E (so inside S). By symmetry, the x coordinate of the centroid is 0. So all we need to do is figure out when \(\bar{y} \geq \tfrac{1}{k}\) (NOTE: There is a bit of ambiguity in the sense that is something on the boundary of S and E inside S or outside of E - I suspect students using greater than or equal to vs just greater than would earn full marks but it is something we should be a bit careful with). In any case, we compute when

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx\end{aligned}\]

Here, the upper curve is the positive half of the circle so

\(\displaystyle f(x) = \sqrt{1 - x^{2}}\)

and the lower curve is the upper half of the ellipse so

\(\displaystyle g(x) = \sqrt{\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}}}.\)

The picture also clearly shows that we are integrating from \(-1 \leq x \leq 1\) (we could have explicitly found these points of intersection as well). Thus, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2\cdot\frac{\pi}{2}\left(1 - \frac{1}{k} \right)}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2}-\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}})\, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2})\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right) )\, dx\end{aligned}\]

where in the last step we factored out a \(1-x^{2}\). Pulling out the terms depending only on k in the integral and using the fact that the integral is the integral of an even function over a symmetric interval yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right)2\int_{0}^{1}(1-x^{2}) )\, dx\\ &= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{k^{2}-1}{k^{2}}\left.\left(x - \frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\ &= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{(k+1)(k-1)}{k^{2}}\left(1 - \frac{1}{3}\right)\\ &= \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k}\end{aligned}\]

Using the inequality derived above, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{k} &\leq \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k} \\ 3\pi &\leq 4(k+1) \\ \frac{3\pi - 4}{4} &\leq k\end{aligned}\]

and this completes the proof.

Now, notice that when \emph{x} is 0, then the two points on the ellipse
are $y = \pm \tfrac{1}{k}$. So the one lying in the upper half of the
plane is $y = \tfrac{1}{k}$. The question asks when is the centroid
outside of E (so inside S). By symmetry, the \emph{x} coordinate of the
centroid is 0. So all we need to do is figure out when
$\bar{y} \geq \tfrac{1}{k}$ (NOTE: There is a bit of ambiguity in the
sense that is something on the boundary of S and E inside S or outside
of E - I suspect students using greater than or equal to vs just greater
than would earn full marks but it is something we should be a bit
careful with). In any case, we compute when

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx
\end{align*}

Here, the upper curve is the positive half of the circle so

$\displaystyle f(x) = \sqrt{1 - x^{2}}$

and the lower curve is the upper half of the ellipse so

$\displaystyle g(x) = \sqrt{\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}}}.$

The picture also clearly shows that we are integrating from
$-1 \leq x \leq 1$ (we could have explicitly found these points of
intersection as well). Thus, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx \\
&= \frac{1}{2\cdot\frac{\pi}{2}\left(1 - \frac{1}{k} \right)}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2}-\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}})\, dx \\
&= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2})\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right) )\, dx
\end{align*}

where in the last step we factored out a $1-x^{2}$. Pulling out the
terms depending only on \emph{k} in the integral and using the fact that
the integral is the integral of an even function over a symmetric
interval yields

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right)2\int_{0}^{1}(1-x^{2}) )\, dx\\
&= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{k^{2}-1}{k^{2}}\left.\left(x - \frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{(k+1)(k-1)}{k^{2}}\left(1 - \frac{1}{3}\right)\\
&= \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k}
\end{align*}

Using the inequality derived above, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} &\leq  \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k} \\
3\pi &\leq 4(k+1) \\
\frac{3\pi - 4}{4} &\leq k
\end{align*}

and this completes the proof.

statement_html:
Let E be the ellipse x2 + k2y2 = 1, where k is a constant with k \(\geq\) 1. Let S be the region inside the circle x2 + y2 = 1, outside E, and above the x-axis.

Find all values of k such that the centroid (centre of mass) of S lies inside S (i.e. outside E). You may use the result of part (a).

Find all values of ''k'' such that the centroid (centre of mass) of ''S'' lies inside ''S'' (i.e. outside ''E''). You may use the result of [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH101/April 2008/Question 7 (a)|part (a)]].
